BIKE_NOTES:
Narrow lanes from 11 to 10 feet, expand shoulder from 3.5 to 4.5 feet, mark shoulder as a bike lane from Eagle Rd. to Ardmore Ave.

The roadway cross-section, even with reducing travel lane and parking lane widths, is not sufficient to accomodate either parking-protected or conventional bike lanes. The area has relatively high density neighborhoods and has businesses and schools in close proximity, the speed (35 mph) and commerical use of the corridor (heavy delivery truck, school bus traffic) may pose safety issues such as impeding visibility when parked. Thus, sharrows are not a safe option up until the Eagle Rd. intersection. At Hillcrest Ave., the speed limit drops to 25 mph and the cross section is reduced to two lanes with a wider (~4 foot) shoulder. Marking the shoulder as a bike lane until the shoulder width reduces at the Ardmore Ave. intersection is the safest and most space-efficient option. Past the Ardmore Ave. intersection, the roadway enters a more rural area with poorer sight lines and is not suitable for safe bicycle travel.

BIKE_PROPOSED: Buffered Bicycle Lanes between Jenkintown Road and Old Welsh Road
BIKE_NOTES:
Notes:
Posted speed: 40mph
AADT: 8,800-15,000 (increasing west to east)
- Given the existing 40mph speed limit, Fitzwatertown Road between Jenkintown Road and Old Welsh Road is eligible for a buffered bicycle lane, but an unbuffered lane is not recommended considering existing traffic volumes and speed. 
- Between Old Welsh Road and York Road, AADT exceed 10,000 vehicles per day. At 40mph, only a separated bicycle lane or shared-use path would be recommended given these volumes.

Restriping Recommendations:
- Between Jenkintown Road and Old Welsh Road, narrow travel lanes to 11 feet, and add space for two 4.5-foot bicycle lanes with 2-foot buffers. Where existing shoulder exceeds 35 feet, a wider bicycle lane and/or buffer may be possible. At intersections with Jenkintown Road, Susquehanna Road, Woodland Road, and Old Welsh Road, left turn lanes leave little room for lanes; sharrows can take the place of lanes for short distances to get cyclists through the intersection (about 200 feet; high-visibility green paint backing would be ideal). Left-turn bike boxes would also improve bicycle safety at these intersections by providing a safe, clear, two-stage turn.

Supplemental recommendations:
- At intersections where proposed bicycle lanes are briefly supplemented by sharrows, MUTCD R4-11 signs (Bicycles May Use Full Lane) would improve safety if implemented through another program.
- Between Old Welsh Road and York Road, existing conditions require physical separation to ensure a safe bicycle facility. If the speed limit were lowered and/or the center turning median were removed, a buffered bicycle lane may be feasible. This type of improvement is out of scope for this project but could be explored through a separate program.
MCD_CONTACT: Paul Leonard - Upper Dublin Twp.

"Paving deferred until Spring 2020 due to utility work.
Resurfacing in 2021"

Ideal / Long-term Treatment - Eliminate center turn lane between intersections to allow for 6 foot bike lanes with a 2 foot buffer.  Lower speed limit to 35mph.

Note - Egypt Road in Lower Providence has similar land uses is only 36 feet wide, has 2, 12 ft lanes between major intersections and despite an AADT >19,000, has no center turn lane.  It also has two 6 foot shoulders that function well as a bike lanes.

BIKE_NOTES:
This one is complicated, but could be a huge win for cyclists of all ages: 
Heading north, between County Way and Red Cedar Dr., buffered bike lanes are feasible. This 700’ segment would connect a library and other Township buildings to a neighborhood and an off-street multi-use trail. 
Between Red Cedar Dr. and Appletree Dr., the ROW narrows to about 29’, enough for 10’ drive lanes and 4.5’ bike lanes. Even though this parallels the multi-use trail I recommend striping this segment for bike lanes because there is a crosswalk at Appletree Dr., which would provide safer access to the multi-use trail than an uncontrolled intersection. Alternatively, a new crosswalk at Red Cedar Dr. would provide a safe crossing to the multi-use trail. 
The trail continues north, ending at Appletree Pl., where I recommend a crosswalk to return bike traffic back on-street. Continuing north to Penn Valley Rd./Hood Blvd., existing shoulders are wide enough for buffered bike lanes. This intersection needs special attention, as it’s got several turn movements, and gets heavy youth pedestrian traffic from the adjacent Pennsbury High School (3000+ students). Fixing this intersection (especially if you could work with Falls Twp. on safe bike lanes on Hood Blvd.) would be a huge win for users of all ages.
North to Thornridge Pass, the road is wide enough for 5-6’ conventional bike lanes, if the center turn lane shrinks to approximately 9’. The shoulders disappear from roughly Thornridge Pass to Vermillion Dr. Technically, sharrows would work for this 1000’ segment, though I would recommend signage and possibly yield markings where bike lanes end. North of Vermillion Dr. existing shoulders are wide enough for buffered bike lanes. I recommend intersection crossing markings north across Tyburn Rd. to get cyclists to/from Fallsington.

Vehicular lanes could also narrow to 11’ to discourage speeding. At Pennswood Village Dr./Tollgate Rd., there should be enough width to drop to 5’ conventional bike lanes, and preserve existing turn lanes, as long as they’re narrowed to 10.5’-11’. 
South to Alberts Way the ROW is wide enough for 5-6’ conventional bike lanes (depending on total ROW width) and 11’ vehicular lanes. At Alberts Way, there is a curbed left-turn lane which narrows the southbound ROW to 14’ Since this is a very short stretch, it is probably acceptable to narrow the SB bike lane to 4’, or at least stripe a shoulder without a bike legend. The St. Mary Medical Center entrance intersection needs a more focused design, but some things to consider: St. Mary’s is a big employer who may appreciate bike commute access; and there are trail entrances here to Core Creek Park.
Continuing south to Heatons Mill Rd., the ROW varies between 42’ and 46’ wide, with a large NB shoulder and no SB shoulder. I recommend a 10’ center turn lane, 11’-12’ vehicular lanes, and 5-6’ conventional bike lanes, depending on total ROW width. South to Bridgetown Pike, the ROW is wide enough for 5’conventional bike lanes, expanding to buffered bike lanes (5-6’ bike lane, 3’ buffer) as you approach Bridgetown Pike.
South of Bridgetown Pike, existing shoulders are generally wide enough for 5-6’ conventional bike lanes. I recommend keeping vehicular lanes to 11’ through this segment. There is a major pinch point at the CSX rail bridge. Speeds are probably high, but a dashed ending to the bike lane and sharrows approaching the underpass could be effective. South to Watson Ave. the ROW is 35-36’ wide, so 11’ vehicle lanes and 6-7’ bike lanes are feasible as you enter Langhorne.

BIKE_NOTES: Install bike lane on left side of roadway between E 4th St. and E 12th St. (9th St intersection will need to be narrowed to one lane) Consider road diet between E 14th St. and E 22nd St. and adding bike lanes on both sides. • 4th St to 22nd St:  The Department would consider reducing the number of travel lanes if a road diet is shown to work. However, this would require a study which is not within the scope of this project. 4th St to 12th Street:  Speed limit = 25 mph. ADT = 10994 vpd.                                                                                                                                                                      • North of College Ave to Baltimore Pk - sharrows are feasible.

OUTREACHNOTE:
Nether Providence, seemed open to the improvements to 320.

Swarthmore, is not interested in the improvements to 320. The road is too high speed and too high traffic. They have municipal facilities on adjacent roads and would like to work with PennDOT to divert cyclists to those facilities.

Springfield, was not able to speak with, but did send along the information
DVRPCNOTES:
Low (~2500) AADT and speed (25 mph) between E 4th St. and E 12th St. allow for bike lanes. There is not adequate ROW from the I-95 overpass to E 14h St. intersection, at which point a road diet would be best for cyclist comfort- AADT is about 4000, a four lane cross section is not necessary. Recommend continuing the road diet through the entirety of the four-lane cross section, which ends at E 22nd St. From there until the Harvey St. intersection, the centerline can be shifted to make space for bike lanes on either side (cartway is about 30' wide). Recommend narrowing lanes at the Harvey Rd. intersection to 10 feet to make space for a bike lane on both shoulders of PA-320 until the shoulder widens considerably after the Sproul Ln. intersection. Recommend continuing a buffered bike lane on either side (which will require removing the shared turn lane from the Canterbury Drive intersection to the 476 overpass, and narrowing lanes after 476 overpass). Once the bike lanes terminate at Fairview Road, recommend installing sharrows on local N-S roads (such as Cornell Ave. or Rutgers Ave.), as PA-320 narrows considerably while maintaining a high AADT (~10000) and becomes unsuitable for cyclists. To establish a connection to the North side of the Swarthmore station, it is recommended to install a bikable shoulder from the Fieldhouse Ln. traffic circle to College Ave. 

UPDATE (9/14/21): Implemented years ago, but no implementation date provided, so it was set to Fall 2019 as an estiamte.

BIKE_NOTES:
Beginning at State Rd., it’s not clear where the PennDOT ROW begins, but there appears to be space for 5’ bike lanes and 11’ travel lanes through Magnolia Ave. The ROW appears to narrow a bit at Main Ave., where there’s an unsignalized crosswalk. I recommend narrowing the travel lanes to 10’ for this approx. 100’ segment just south of Main Ave. Please restripe the existing crosswalk and consider including shark teeth yield triangles as well. North of Magnolia Ave., sharrows are appropriate to guide cyclists to the SEPTA station and under the rail overpass. 
This is a really worthwhile connection and seems like low-hanging fruit from a design perspective.
Note: A previous DVRPC study (https://www.dvrpc.org/reports/14052.pdf) recommends sidewalks and sharrows here. Since sidewalks are off the table as part of a resurfacing, bike lanes seem like a good alternative, but it's worth checking with the Twp. first to see if there are any plans for sidewalks here.

BIKE_NOTES: Beginning in the south, from Park Dr. to Fairway Dr., existing shoulders are generally wide enough for buffered bike lanes (2’-3’ buffer, 5’ bike lane). At the intersection w/ Almshouse Rd., this would require narrowing some/all of the six travel or turn lanes (!) to allow space for a conventional bike lane through the intersection. Continuing north to Deer Run Dr., shoulders are too narrow for bike facilities unless you reduce the lane count and/or narrow the existing lanes. Between Deer Run Dr. and Sugar Bottom Rd., the existing shoulders are again wide enough for buffered bike lanes. There are existing rumble strips just outside the shoulder striping, which would be an interesting complement to a buffered bike lane on a high-volume road like this. As noted by the County and Bike Coalition, this segment has great connectivity benefits, and could be a signature connection for the county.

BIKE_NOTES:
Heading north from Tyburn Road, the ROW is generally too narrow for bike lanes, and with heavy truck traffic, sharrows seem inappropriate. North from Post Rd., there is a generous (8’+) parking lane in each direction, which appears to be well used. Sharrows may be appropriate from here north, as the land use becomes more neighborhood-residential. Between Philadelphia Ave. and Bridge St. there is no parking lane, buffered bike lanes are feasible, and may help to reduce speeding. Continuing north through Morrisville Borough to W. Trenton Ave.., sharrows are appropriate if on-street parking cannot be removed for buffered bike lanes. North to Yardley Morrisville Rd, sharrrows are technically appropriate (35mph), though I know speeding is more of an issue here. It may be helpful to stripe the shoulders to narrow the travel lanes down to about 10.5’, which may slow traffic closer to 35mph, and provide a narrow shoulder for confident cyclists.
Please restripe all existing crosswalks, most of which are in Morrisville Borough.

The priority should be to allow cyclists to turn onto Sutphin Rd., which provides safe access to several neighborhoods and enables an easy connection to the Pennsbury middle schools’ campus. 
North of Sutphin Rd., the roadway is too narrow for bike lanes and the speed limit almost too high for sharrows unless we’re using them to guide cyclists to the Canal via Black Rock Road.
This one is very feasible and makes a great impact on local connectivity.

BIKE_NOTES:
LTS: 3,4 
AADT: South: ~7500, North: ~13000
Speed Limit: 35, reduces to 25 in Marcus Hook and Highland Ave. segment

There are already buffered bike lanes in both directions from the state line to Green St. intersection. Changes to share the road, until the bike lanes pick back up at the Church St. intersection. The lanes head off of the segment at the Price St. intersection. 

I believe the north segment of US-13 has too high volume for conventional bike lanes, and parking and intersection configuration makes buffered or parking-protected bike lanes difficult. I recommend enhancing or adding markings (sharrows in Marcus Hook, dashed bike lane edgelines through intersections) and exploring a parallel route with less traffic to add bike facilities.
PENNDOTNOTS: Bike lanes/ Sharrows
BCGPNOTES: Overlaps with ECG. ECG notes from Daniel Paschall: Shawn Megill-Legendre has led the coordination with DelDOT and PennDOT to ensure continuous bike lanes across the state border into Marcus Hook. It would also be great to get bike lanes installed going from Marcus Hook into Chester, from Price St to Highland Ave. See the Circuit Trails map for that segment as "Planned". Also, it looks like only sharrows would be able to fit within the right-of-way for downtown Marcus Hook, Green St to Church St, but that would still be an improvement (also "Planned" on the Circuit Map).
PENNFEASISCREENNOTE:
Maintaining existing bicycle facilities is recommended. North bound lane, need to ensure plans reflect tie in with DelDOT's bike lanes as discussed with DVRPC & DelDOT. Prefer to add double white lines for bike lanes where there is parking on street. The installation of sharrows from Green St to Church St in Marcus Hook appears feasible to connect the existing bike lanes north and south of this segment. Bike lanes are possible over Markus Hook Creek Bridge, butthere is at least one parking spot impact in WB direction, just west of the bridge at the intersection with Walnut.  

North of Price St, the existing bike lane terminates.  The roadway width from Price St to Highland Ave width varies from 30' to 36'. Installation of bike lanes appears feasible from Price St to Harwick St. 

On W 4th St from Harwick St to Highland Ave and on Highland Ave, roadway width appears to be 36' with on-street parking heavily utilized on both sides, therefore removal of parking for bike lanes not recommended along this segment. The installation of sharrows appears feasible along this segment.

On W 9t St from Highland Ave to Engle St, ADT = 11,000 and roadway width appears to be 36' with one travel lane in each direction and on-street parking either restricted or not heavily utilized. Installation of bike lanes appears feasible along this segment. Access to Memorial Park seems to be better served by utilizing a local road (W 7th St or W 6th St) insead of W 9th St (SR 13) due to high traffic volume. 

North of Engle St, roadway width generally appears to be 36' with one travel lane in each direction and on-street parking. On-street parking appears to be heavily utilized in most areas along this segment. Therefore, removal of on-street parking and installation of bike lanes not recommended. Installation of sharrows not feasible due to volumes/speed limit.
